JOHN SHIMKUS, A REPRESENTATIVE INCONGRESS FROM THE STATE OF ILLINOIS</opening> <speaker>Mr. Shimkus</speaker> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">We will ask staff to close the back door, please, and ask the committee to now come to order, and I will recognize myself for 5 minutes for an opening statement.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">I want to thank all our witnesses for joining us today. We are especially grateful for those of you who have traveled significant distances to be with us today to share your stories about the hurricanes that tore through our country this fall and about the impact of those hurricanes on the environment.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">We know that many of you are still in the trenches of dealing with the response and recovery efforts, so your willingness to take the time to be here today does not go unnoticed.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">This fall, the continental United States and some United States territories in the Caribbean experienced severe weather from five hurricanes, including extensive damage due to landfall from four storms.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">Hurricane Harvey impacted Texas and Louisiana; Hurricane Irma hit Florida, Georgia, Puerto Rico, and the U.S. Virgin Islands; Hurricane Maria, again, hit Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands; and Tropical Storm Nate impacted Louisiana and Mississippi.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">The Energy and Commerce Committee is conducting a series of hearings to look at the response and recovery efforts conducted during this hurricane season so we can figure out what went well and what we could we have done better, what we need to do is going--and what we need to do going forward.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">We are also focused on what Congress can do to assist the impacted communities as they work to get back on their feet.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">Today we are focused on the environmental impacts of these hurricanes and the response efforts. No two hurricanes are alike, and a storm's individual characteristics, like the speed, intensity, and amount of precipitation, play a large role in the extent of the storm's impact on natural resources and the environment.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">For example, as we will hear from several of our witnesses, Hurricane Harvey may have significantly impacted several Superfund sites in Houston because of the record rainfall and flooding.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">Likewise, in Puerto Rico, Hurricanes Irma and Maria uncovered the intensified issues associated with aging and inefficient energy infrastructure, contaminated sites that are rapidly multiplying, landfills that are already overflowing, and possibly the most contaminated drinking water supply in the United States.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">Residents across the island are still without power and reliable source of--and a reliable source of drinking water. Many are drinking potentially contaminated water because water purification systems have largely failed in the wake of the storm, and in the municipality of Dorado citizens resorted to drinking well water from Superfund sites.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">Today, we will look at the response efforts by the Environmental Protection Agency and the States for the impacted communities. We will consider environmental issues in the hurricane-impacted communities such as the availability of clean drinking water, the potential for air releases, the impact on Superfund sites and solid and hazardous waste disposal facilities, and risk management and emergency response plans.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">We hope to hear from the affected EPA regional administrators about their efforts, what they accomplished, what remains to be done, and what can be done better in the future and how Congress can assist.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">We will also hear from several private sector witnesses from academia as well as people who are serving in the boots- on-the ground roles in Texas and Puerto Rico, and people who can weigh in on what needs to be done regarding the drinking water systems in the affected communities.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">Again, I thank all our witnesses for being here. I hope the discussions will start today about the response and recovery efforts, the National Response Framework, and about whether statutory or other changes need to be made.</paragraph>

There are so many different aspects to preventing, planning for, responding to the natural disasters, as the chairman has said, and these events are taking a toll on our communities, also on our Nation.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">And so much is involved in it--today, the environmental aspects, but also looking at the health aspects, and we know that they all have to work hand in hand.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">I have got a piece of legislation, H.R. 1876, the Good Samaritan Health Professionals Act, that deals with that one component of making certain that people are cared for appropriately.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">But we thank you for being here. She's going to be sitting at the dais, but per committee rule she can't ask questions, she can't make an opening statement. But when she comes, I will make sure I recognize her.</paragraph>

<opening>OPENING STATEMENT OF HON. PAUL TONKO, A REPRESENTATIVE INCONGRESS FROM THE STATE OF NEW YORK</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="HON. PAUL TONKO"> With that, I yield back my time and yield 5 minutes to the ranking member, Mr. Tonko, for 5 minutes. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Tonko</speaker> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Mr. Tonko">Thank you, Mr. Chair.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Mr. Tonko">It is important that we are holding this hearing and I thank you for doing that.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Mr. Tonko">I was sad to hear the news that our friend, the former ranking member of this subcommittee and the current ranking member of our Health Subcommittee, Gene Green, will be retiring at the end of the 115th Congress.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Mr. Tonko">I know Gene was here a few moments ago. But I want to thank him for his friendship and know that he will--and I certainly know that he will be fighting for disaster assistance for Houstonians for the next 13 months. So we wish him well.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Mr. Tonko">And I thank all of our witnesses for being here. It is great to have EPA witnesses join us on this very important topic. I hope Administrator Pruitt will appear before the subcommittee at some point in the near future as well.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Mr. Tonko">I want to especially take this opportunity to welcome Administrator Peter Lopez. Mr. Lopez and I have worked together for many years. His former Assembly district overlapped a portion of New York's 20th Congressional District.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Mr. Tonko">Our constituents were hit hard by Hurricane Irene and Tropical Storm Lee, and we well know that disasters don't discriminate.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Mr. Tonko">Peter, you are an outstanding public servant, and I wish you well in your new role and it is great to have you at the witness table today.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Mr. Tonko">Mother Nature does not discriminate. She doesn't care if you are a Republican or a Democrat, and our Government must be ready to respond to help everyone get back on their feet.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Mr. Tonko">So I hope you can take the lessons learned over the years both in the response and recovery efforts and apply them to assist our fellow Americans in need now.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Mr. Tonko">We know the recovery effort will be long. But, sadly, in Puerto Rico and the United States Virgin Islands the response effort is still underway.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Mr. Tonko">Far too many Americans continue to live without electricity or safe drinking water and that is simply unacceptable.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Mr. Tonko">On today's panels we will hear about the work done in the aftermath of Hurricanes Harvey, Irma, and Maria, to address environmental concerns.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="Mr. Tonko">EPA plays an important role in disaster response by assessing and restoring water systems and Superfund sites, responding to chemical and oil spills, and monitoring air quality.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="Mr. Tonko">I know there will be a wide variety of issues addressed today including Superfund, chemical safety, air emissions, and debris management.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="Mr. Tonko">I am particularly concerned about water systems, which we know are often aging and in disrepair, even without the stress of a disaster.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="18" speaker="Mr. Tonko">There are legitimate questions as to whether State revolving fund loans are the most appropriate vehicle to get communities back on their feet following such devastation.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="19" speaker="Mr. Tonko">In Texas and in Florida, flood waters were contaminated with bacteria and toxins. Water included high concentrations of E. coli as well as elevated levels of lead, arsenic, and other heavy metals.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="20" speaker="Mr. Tonko">In Puerto Rico, we have heard stories of people drinking from and bathing in contaminated rivers. There have been a number of reported cases of leptospirosis.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="21" speaker="Mr. Tonko">The media even reported people using a well located--a well located on Superfund site, which only after the fact was determined to meet Federal drinking water standards.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="22" speaker="Mr. Tonko">These examples show the direness of the circumstances that Americans faced following these disasters--no power, no clean water, and driven to acts of desperation.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="23" speaker="Mr. Tonko">These hurricanes should serve as a reminder that EPA is one of our Nation's most essential public health agencies. EPA has important work to do as recovery for these disasters begins.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="24" speaker="Mr. Tonko">But the drastic proposed reduction to EPA's budget, personnel, and environmental safeguards will make it harder to fulfil its mission including supporting disaster response and disaster recovery.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="25" speaker="Mr. Tonko">Preserving a strong EPA is critical to the health of Americans. These storms have made that clear. A robust EPA will make communities more resilient.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="26" speaker="Mr. Tonko">For example, today we will hear about the risks posed to Superfund sites by disasters and the work EPA has done to assess these sites both before and after storms.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="27" speaker="Mr. Tonko">But the best and perhaps only way to mitigate the risks to these sites is through actual remediation. Reducing funding to the Superfund program will not make cleanups happen any quicker and will not make sites less vulnerable to storms.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="28" speaker="Mr. Tonko">I would also be remiss if I did not mention climate change and the role EPA should be playing in addressing that threat. If we continue to ignore climate change, increasingly severe disasters will become the new normal and we can expect many more hearings like this one in the future.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="29" speaker="Mr. Tonko">I hope we can work together to ensure EPA has the resources necessary to support disaster response efforts and make our communities more resilient to disasters before they occur.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="30" speaker="Mr. Tonko"> I look forward to hearing from the witnesses today and yield back and, again, thank you, Mr. Chairman. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Shimkus</speaker> <paragraph paraId="31" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">Gentleman yields back the time.</paragraph>
